title: What's the point of virtual reality? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: What's the point of virtual reality? It’s an interesting question. Not “What is Virtual Reality” or “What is the purpose of Virtual Reality” but “what is the point?? I mean, you could say “what’s the point of a steam engine (train)?” You can discuss in detail what they are and what their purpose is, but compared to modern locomotives, there isn’t much of a point. So this is provocative, but a good thought experiment. Let’s turn it around and think about another way to experience different realities - books. What’s the point of a book? I mean, it’s not real. People that read books pay more attention to people that don’t exist, and aren’t aware of what is going on around them. I think we should all just put our books down and look at one another. That’s what my mom says, except she’s talking about the Internet and cell phones. So - here’s my take on the point of VR. You can do things you can’t in real life. VR doesn’t have to “look” real - but when you are in it, it seems real. That’s the point. That simple sense of reality can do marvelous things. It can put you in places that are dangerous or impossible.  People die on Everest. Sure, a VR expedition is nothing like the real thing - but it seems real. Just watching a movie won’t give you that visceral thrill. It won’t make you say “Wow! That’s steep!” EVEREST VR — Sólfar Studios Can a book help you with a fear of heights?  Richie's Plank Experience on Steam “Walk a mile in my shoes”. It can help with racism. Numerous experiments can put you in the body of someone of another ethnic or racial group. This has been shown to help with empathy.  Empathy/Diversity Learning Empathy Through Virtual Reality: Multiple Strategies for Training Empathy-Related Abilities Using Body Ownership Illusions in Embodied Virtual Reality It can allow you to practice things that you normally couldn’t practice:  Chop and Drop VR on Steam I think that’s the point of VR. And of course, games are a lot of fun. There’s a point to fun!

One huge point is that for architecture visualization the VR display gives the right sense of scale. When viewing a 3D model of a planned building for example. When looking at a picture on a conventional display (e.g. laptop display) we don't see it with realistic perspective, are just looking at a picture that is a part of the overall view. Especially for interior spaces it is really difficult to understand the size of the space, typically it seems smaller than it actually is. With VR goggles it feels as if you were in the space and we seem to easily see the scale correctly. The stereoscopic depth view of course helps there too. This way these cheap goggles are a big deal for evaluating building plans I think.
